I was at the stage of talking about drought proofing of properties. Bearing in mind that this is a most dreadful drought that we are having in Australia currently, I think that for the future the government will certainly need to look at drought proofing measures and taxation benefits that may be applicable to the farming community to enable it to take a lot of the preventative measures that are required to ensure that a property remains viable during what we are seeing as an extreme drought throughout Australia. Instances of these measures are on-farm water storage, on-farm grain storage and land improvements to overcome any degradation of the land that might occur as a result of the drought. I know that the landcare program has been especially effective in my electorate, areas of which have been amongst the leaders in landcare measures. They certainly have put those programs to very effective use. The government will need to look at putting in place funding arrangements and taxation benefits that will in fact drought proof a lot of properties throughout Australia. speaker: Mr Reid (Bendigo) (10.01 A.m.)
theText: Mr Deputy Speaker, I acknowledge the government's1466 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 I particularly recall the situation in Victoria, when we went through a disastrous drought in 1982, and the ramifications of that and of the Ash Wednesday fires. After the fires had subsided and the extent of the damage had been assessed, the Victorian state government at the time embarked on a wide ranging program of counterdisaster measures which they put in place through legislation. Those provisions have remained in place since that time. People need to know that, if they are affected by drought or by fire, there are guidelines to assist them in understanding what relief will be made available by the government. We need to ensure that there is an understanding by people in the rural community and by other people affected by natural disasters that there is something there to assist them in each particular case. It is absolutely vital that we ensure that people in the rural community are looked after in cases of drought, because they are one of the major export earners in Australia and they produce a lot of Australia's wealth. We have a very good reputation for the cleanliness of our agricultural product, and that reputation has spread throughout the world. People acknowledge that food produced in Australia by our rural community is in fact clean: it is acceptable worldwide, and Australia has an extremely good food production reputation. If the proper drought relief measures are not in place, we are in serious danger of losing many of our good farmers. There has been a movement away from rural pursuits in recent years where young people have chosen to leave the farm and take up other careers. The average age of people farming in Australia has increased. We are in danger of losing even more young people from the farming community as a result of the ravages of this drought, which extends throughout Queensland and New South Wales, ancl now southerly down into Victoria. The fact that drought affects everyone is borne out by what happened during the 1982 drought. Drought affects the farmers who are producing the food, it affects small business around the towns which support the rural communities, and it ultimately flows on to large business throughout capital cities. That was never more evident than during the 1982 drought. I am sure that in Queensland and New South Wales people would also be feeling the impact now in the small business communities, and it would be flowing on into Sydney and Brisbane. Farms are not producing anything. The land is ravaged by the weather and is degraded as a result, and a lot of the topsoil is lost. People are placed in a situation where they have to face up to the elements and the deterioration of their farm property. For financial or physical reasons many of them are forced to give up and leave the farm. We have lost many good farmers as a result. Just the same, in small towns the mainstays of those communities-the small businesses-are affected. They provide goods and services to the farming community and are unable to withstand the economic and social trauma that is handed down through the deterioration of the farming pursuits. People lose their economic and social viability in those towns and they leave. Then, because of the declining population, government services are withdrawn. Many small towns are shrinking as a result of the impact of the drought we are going through now. Those effects flow on to larger cities. Following the 1982 drought Melbourne was inundated with people who had left rural communities ancl had gone to Melbourne seeking employment. There is an impact on the economic activity in capital city areas because most of the manufacturers are based in the metropolitan area. Some of the large agricultural manufacturing enterprises are operating in those areas and they are seriously affected. Thursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1467 I want to touch on the relationship between the present drought and the difficulties that we are experiencing, and the need to put something permanently in place that will provide guidelines for the rural community in this great time of need. There are a number of parallels between our policy and the government's policy. I want to enumerate some of those. The parallels between the two policies include the provision of immediate farm family income support. This is absolutely vital. The coalition makes provision for support through a revamped farm household support scheme and the suspension of the assets test on welfare payments, the government via its new drought relief payment. There is also improved access to Austudy for children from farm families in drought areas by exempting them from the on-farm assets test for this benefit. One thing that would exacerbate the tragedy of a drought would be if children, through economic necessity, were withdrawn from their studies. Further parallels involve greater flexibility and increased funding under the rural adjustment scheme for farmers experiencing drought in exceptional circumstances and the provision of assistance through the rural adjustment scheme for up to 12 months after the drought breaks. This is important because the ramifications of the drought go on, even after it has rained, because of the deterioration of the land. A lot of the topsoil, a lot of trees and a lot of native grasses are lost when it does rain, particularly if there is a heavy downpour. We need to be able to rehabilitate the land and to make sure that the land becomes viable in the future. I am certainly not condemning what the government has done. I think that it has met some of the concerns of the rural community but I am concerned that the package did nothing for small business operators in many of those drought areas because their cash flow has been absolutely decimated. We can understand that people in the farming community are going through this dreadful time when they do not have any income. There is additional pressure on small business operators who are providing them with goods and services to sustain them on the farm in the hope that the rural seasons will improve. I would have thought that the government could have looked at providing some form of package to small business in many of those rural areas where they are servicing the farming community. Many of those small businesses will be facing a dreadful time at the moment because, whilst the income support to the families is very much welcomed, it will only be enough to sustain those families. There will not be much left after that to provide for additional services and goods from small businesses in the area and, of course, that will affect their viability. I do have some very serious concerns about the impact of the drought on small business. A solution could have been achieved by returning severe or exceptional drought to the natural disaster relief arrangements and that would have given small business and farmers access to long-term concessional loans. I know that a loan still has to be paid back but, if it were a reasonably attractive loan on a long-term basis, interest repayments would be easier for those small businesses and it might help some of them to overcome the effects of the drought. I am pleased to have had the opportunity to speak both before and after the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) made his announcement and I do welcome the provisions that have been made. I do not believe that drought relief should be a political issue between parties. I think that what we should be trying to do is to arrive at a bipartisan position where there are strong guidelines in place. Farmers should know what the rules of 1468 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 the game are if a drought descends upon them. They should know that there is provision on an ongoing basis to help them not only for the drought period but also for a period of time after the drought so that they can rehabilitate the land and get it back into full production again. I think the government should now be looking at providing long-term benefits to the farming community, particularly to farmers who want to try to drought proof their property or to make provisions for it. I know the honourable member for Lyons( Mr Adams) would appreciate that. Whilst Tasmania is not in the grip of this drought, there are some areas that are affected. It is probably not a drought by outback Queensland and outback New South Wales standards but certainly there has been a lower level of production for them. The member would understand that there is a need for an ongoing provision of measures for farmers, particularly in the area of drought proofing of properties. The tax benefits that might be given to farmers allow them to provide a bit of insulation against the ravages of the drought that we are currently going through. I believe the important thing is the need for long-term planning to ensure that farmers are kept on the farm. Farmers are one of the major economic stimulants to the economy and, of course, one of our greatest export earners. Their expertise should not be lost to the Australian community. Amendment Bill (No.2). It has many parts to it and it deals with many amendments to many of the acts dealing with rural industries. I certainly support the government's amendments to the bill, which do some tidying up work. I am opposed to the opposition's amendment, which has now been made redundant by the government's announcement yesterday in relation to assisting rural Australia in dealing with the drought issues. I basically want to support and speak about the wine industry. At the request of the wine industry, the bills allow a levy to be raised so that we can look at marketing, which includes wine promotion, wine export control, the wine label integrity program-which is so important in making sure we have integrity in all of our industries and in quality control-and how we describe Australian wine. These bills work through these issues. There is also the research component. The Wine and Brandy Corporation has a statutory responsibility to coordinate and fund research and development undertaken on behalf of the industry. The government provides matching funds for this expenditure on a dollar for dollar basis. In other words, the government recognises that, although the industry is an expanding one and quite lucrative, there is a great deal of research and development needed to ensure the viability and continuing success of the industry. The bill also ends the exemption that smaller winemakers, those processing less than 10 tonnes of product, had from paying a levy. As non-payers, they had no recognition in the decisions and operations of the corporation and its regulatory functions, nor were they able to seek specific assistance with research that involves the smaller wine grower. In the area where I come from in Tasmania there are small producers on small blocks. They sometimes miss out on the research opportunities from government agricultural departments and state departments. I think they also miss out on the research done in the bigger areas on how we are structuring research in the rural industries. For a small annual fee that constitutes the minimum levy rate, smaller winemakers will have the right to represent their interests at the annual general meetings and to receive services and information from the corporation. Some of the smaller winemakers rely on larger winemakers

speaker: Mr Adams (Lyons) (10.16 A.m.)
theText: I support the Primary Industries and Energy LegislationThursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1469 to process grapes and to convert them into wine under instructions for a fee. The wine is then returned to the smaller winemaker to market. Under the current legislation, the larger winemaker is seen as the producer and is liable for a levy on the wine. This cost is added to the fee charged to smaller winemakers making them pay for the levy anyway but without being able to attend, debate or vote in the industry's meetings. The act allows all winemakers to participate fully in the decision making of their industry. Many small producers will not be exporters, but the changes to the domestic market directly affect them and it is important for them to have their say. Winemaking is becoming a very important industry in Australia. Annual production of beverage wine is about 450 miIlion lit res, from 600,000 to 700,000 tonnes of wine grapes. The gross value of production of wine grapes is approximately $300 million, and the gross value of wine sales is about $1,200 miIlion. Wine grapes are grown in all states of Australia, with South Australia, of course, being the main producing state. There are about 4,000 grape growers supplying about 700 wineries. This industry is a very successful value adding export industry, with exports having grown from 11 million litres-worth $21 million-in 1985-86, to 103 million litres-worth $293 millionin 1992-93, and an estimated $394 miIlion in 1993-94. Export'> now accOlmt for over a quarter of production. The industry has set a target for exports of $1 billion per annum by the year 2000-a very big ask. Our main markets, by volume, are the United Kingdom, New Zealand, Sweden, the United States, Canada and Japan. Figures are now showing that the world wine market is saturated. In 1992, the world wine production of 29.4 billion litres exceeded consumption, which was 23 billion litres. But Australia's position in the cleaner southern hemisphere, Australia's quest for the high quality market and the fact that our wines are fruity and affordable have ensured a firm demand in the world picture. Other countries are a little nervous for their industries, as Australia's wine is beginning to be seen by connoisseurs as being in the premier league. I am sure you would agree with that, Mr Deputy Speaker. Tasmania is benefiting from the interest of wine producers. There are 59 registered wine growers in Tasmania, and there may be a few more growing grapes as a hobby. They are spread all over the state and grow a wide variety of grapes. The Tasmanian industry is relatively young, apart from our veteran wine grower, Claud Alcorso, who started making wine as a hobby after being told that basicaIly he could not grow grapes in Tasmania. He now has a very successful industry. It is surprising that Tasmania was slower than other states to see the potential. I think that people did not realise that our climate is very similar to those of Rome and south-western Spain, where there is plenty of wine grown. But it may also have something to do also with the exceIlent Cascade and Boags beers that have been brewed for over 100 years in Tasmania. Perhaps old habits die hard in Tasmania. However, in 1992-93 Tasmania produced 1,087 tonnes of grapes, half of which were red and half of which were white, giving Tasmania a chance for a nice range of table wines. We are certainly catching up now to some of the levels of the wines of the other states. Although we will probably never get to the same levels of production as exist in other states, because of our size, I think we can continue to produce first class wines and fit into our niche markets. I have noticed that Tasmania's wines have been seen in many mainland shows and are winning prizes across the country. 1470 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 But, as in all primary industries, there are many pitfalls. Unless smaller growers have access to marketing skills and research and development expertise, competition for export markets may soon see a promising industry fail. Levies are seen as an insurance. They are the safeguard to ensure that winemaking prospers, and that Australia is competing in its own right in what has been seen in the past as a European monopoly. The bill also deals with the Farm Household Support Act of 1992 and tidies up some matters in relation to that. The previous speaker, the member for Bendigo( Mr Reid), mentioned the drought issues and did touch on Tasmania. Some parts of my electorate are having a very tough time and, though conditions are not as severe as in western Queensland, where I spent some of my youth, or New South Wales, there are areas around St Marys and on the lower east coast and into the southern midlands of Tasmania which are extremely dry and where production levels are down. So any of the farmers in those areas would possibly have the opportunity of getting the benefit of some of the government's drought relief measures announced yesterday. Mr Tim Fischer-Are there drought declared areas in Tasmania? was very important was the need for a bipartisan approach to the broader picture of drought in terms of sustainability and whole farm management. I know the Farmers Federation in Tasmania is working very hard with its landcare officer to get farmers onto a whole farm management approach, and it has set some very ambitious time spans for that. The idea is to get farmers to look at their water catchment, at what coverage of trees and shrubbage exists within the farm, and to look at the farm as a whole and not one part of it at a time. We really come back to what we call sustainability, in getting agriculture to a sustainable situation. Of course, droughts and downturns in the rural area affect small towns. They have affected some of the areas in my electorate, and any assistance that we can get to some of our people will also sustain those small towns. I support the bill and the government amendments that go with it. Amendment negatived. Original question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. The government amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1994 will amend section 159 of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Code Act 1994. The proposed amendments are technical amendments to ensure that the national registration authority for agricultural and veterinary chemicals, the NRA, can require a chemical company to provide certain information. The information would concern the reconsideration of chemical products registration and decisions concerning the suspension or cancellation of permits and chemical products. Furthermore the above information, when provided by a chemical company, will be recognised as protected registration information in accordance with the provisions of section 59, as was originally intended. This will ensure that information provided to the NRA in accordance with section 159 will not be commercially exploited by others without due regard to the payment of compensation to the originator of the information. Consideration resumed from 31 August. Second Reading Mr O'KEEFE (Burke-Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport) (10.35 a.m.)-I move: That the bill be now read a second time. The Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill makes a number of 'technical' amendments to the Export Market Development Grants Act. Broadly, these amendments will allow better management, focus and control in relation to approved joint venture and consortium, and approved trading houses; give greater promotional focus to certain expenditure; and provide Austrade with the power to introduce and administer a system of accreditation for export grants consultants. Included under the scheme since 1990-91, as single entity claimants, have been groupings of exporters known as approved joint venture and approved consortium. This facility allows exporters to present a group approach to markets where their aggregation of effort can demonstrate advantages over single supplier promotion. The advantage for exporters is that they remain as individuals for all other purposes under the EMDG scheme, including the ability to receive grants in their own right for their other export promotional endeavours. The facility is project based, and is at the discretion of Austrade within the confines of the act, and ministerially approved guidelines. Approved trading houses are individual entities, which, by virtue of their international network and trading expertise, are able to assist the promotion of the product of exporters who lack the funds and ability to undertake EMDG eligible promotion. Currently Austrade has only 30 days in which to make all of the inquiries necessary to a decision whether or not to grant approved joint venture-consortium status, or approved trading house status. This period, in many instances, has proved too short to allow for consideration Thursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1473 of all the facts. A period of 60 days should overcome this barrier to good decision making whilst, at the same time, not unduly delaying the processing of applications. Given approved status, it is important that the entity may be monitored for adherence to the conditions of approval. The act is deficient in regard to providing Austrade with the power to reconsider approved status in the light of subsequent unsatisfactory performance, or where guidelines have been amended to reOect changed government attitude. This bill rectifies the situation. The general limit to the number of EMD grants receivable by claimants is eight. With the focus of approval for joint venture-consortium being project specific, rather than the broad scope of activity afforded other categories of claimant, and in the light of experience, the control provided by this bill in limiting the life of approved joint venture-consortium to a threeto five-year range is seen as an important administrative control. In lieu of non-claimable accommodation, entertainment and sustenance expenses, the scheme provides an eligible expenditure allowance of $200 per day-maximum of 21 days per overseas trip. Currently, this allowance is assessed on the basis of the prime and principal purpose of the totality of trip, rather than focusing on the actual time devoted to eligible promotional activity. This bill, on the one hand, eliminates the possibility of the scheme supporting overseas vacations and, on the other hand, does not eliminate from grants consideration those exporters who may wish to undertake limited promotional activity whilst overseas primarily for other reasons. Finally, there are a number of consultants who provide a service to EMDG claimants with respect to the preparation and lodgement of claims. In 1992-93, over 50 per cent of claims were lodged through, or with the assistance of, consultants. As part of Austrade's enhancement of EMDG risk management, accreditation will provide a mechanism for improving the accuracy of lodged claims, thereby freeing some investigatory resources for use elsewhere within the scheme. I commend this bill to honourable members. is with some fear and trepidation that I stand to make my first formal maiden speech in this extraordinary chamber, but nevertheless I will overcome this and proceed. I restate my doubts about this chamber and its modus operandi. I do not, in any way, reOect on those who are working hard to make it work. The more fundamental, threshold question is whether it should exist, and whether it should meet concurrent with the House as a whole. These are judgments to be made again, and reviewed further down the track. I welcome the opportunity to address the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill 1994. Once more, there are amendments to this legislation. It is noteworthy that since 1988 there have been seven amendments to the parent act, and this is the eighth, making this probably one of the most amended pieces of legislation coming before this parliament. At an average of more than one amendment per year over the last few years, I hardly think that the government has grounds for self-congratulation, since I also note that by and large the amendments that have been introduced have been administrative, aimed at tightening up provisions that have been open to abuse. This current round of amendments is of a similar ilk. I might add that members should not be unmindful of the fact that for each and every amending bill to go through the parliament, there is a cost tag of about $1 million-that is,
