theText: Leader of the National Party of Australia) (10.40 a.m.)-It1474 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 by dividing the total cost of operation of the federal parliament by the pieces of legislation, amending legislation and acts of parliament that pass in the course of each 12-month period. Therefore, there is an obligation on government to be conscious of a need to approach the whole process of amending legislation on a very sensible basis, and on an efficient basis, so that it is not coming forward constantly with amendments, but so that some effort is made to group those, and to provide that the legislation in its original form is correct in the first place. These constant reviews and changes to the scheme do not really provide a stable and secure environment for exporters. Nevertheless, we are not intending to oppose this amending legislation to this scheme, because it represents access to grants for businesses that might not otherwise qualify, and it does tighten procedures, which, by extension, may well result in savings that can be passed on to other small exporters. It is probably no coincidence that the amendments now before us, which impact upon grants to approved trading houses and approved joint ventures, follow on the heels of the effort of the Australian National Audit Office on the export market development grants scheme-which, I might add, was a scheme found to be wanting. This raises another question: what other shortcomings in the legislation are only revealed by detailed examination. I have said before-and I am not averse to repeating myself-it is time for this piece of legislation to be completely overhauled and for there to be a total redrafting. This should be originated, not in the rarefied environment of Austrade, but in an environment that permits the fullest and widest consultation between the interested parties, as well as with the ANAO. I believe that it is important for this legislation to give more substantive guarantees that it is comprehensive and fulfils the needs of the export sector, while at the same time protecting the tax dollar from improper application. While I am advocating a review of legislation, I would also advocate the need for Austrade itself to be the subject of a total efficiency audit. The McKinsey report on emerging exporters, when it was brought down some time ago, was not a testament to the efficiency of Austrade. It has been 10 years since the practices of Austrade were the subject of scrutiny by the ANAO, and I fail to see why this has not been remedied. In my view, the extent of legislative amendment does nothing to contribute to the confidence of the business community in the overall Austrade act. Indeed, the constant change that has been a feature of this piece of legislation may well contribute to greater business uncertainty. On the issue of registration of consultants, I support the addition of provisions that will more effectively regulate the standard of consultants engaged in the preparation of EMDG claims on behalf of business. A provision such as this is long overdue. It will hopefully speed up the process of claim examination by the department and reduce delays in the delivery of grants. I also welcome the intention of the amendment to tie grants more closely to actual promotional activity being undertaken overseas and to clarify with greater precision the conditions under which the grant will be paid. Again, I make the observation: why was this not previously addressed? I find it extraordinary that it needed an audit by the ANAO to bring about a tightening up on some of these provisions. Had it not been for the audit, I can only assume that this provision and those previously referred to relating to grants would otherwise have continued when clearly they were inappropriate. Why else would the legislation be subject to amendment? Thursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1475 The fact of the matter is that the government's overall approach to international trade is less than adequate. And while the export market development grants scheme probably offers some assistance to exporters, the government's longer term strategies are floundering. The government's self-congratulation on its trade figures is a sham. We all know what the picture is: imports up, exports down. The minister is not averse to quoting figures on the success of Australia's export drive. But when we analyse the figures a very different picture emerges. The fact is that whilst the government proclaims the Asia-Pacific as Australia's most significant market, in reality our exports are losing market share. Note that I said 'market share'; I did not say 'volume' because one would expect the volume to be increasing, particularly as we are caught in the slipstream of growth that is taking place in the Asian region with the ASEAN economic tigers, north-east Asia and elsewhere. It is clear that our exporters are by degrees sticking in a rut and it is for government to facilitate export. There is more to come. How can the government take any comfort from the recent report of the APEC eminent persons group? Our only claim to fame from the report is that it expresses a direction towards free trade. It is motherhood stuff, pure and simple. Of course, free trade on a sensible basis is a desirable end, but the question is how it is to be achieved. The report sheds no light on that at all, but it certainly does not close the door on some sort of discriminatory trade block. I suggest to the government that it read the small print with all of the aspects of APEC and the APEC eminent persons group report. In the context of our trading effort, a whole lot more effort is required. I remind the chamber that, in the case of Malaysia, our trade has increased in volume-I fully acknowledge that-but it has increased in minuscule proportions to the huge growth in the Malaysian economy. As a consequence our market share of Malaysian trade has fallen by some 10 per cent. In other words, Australia is not cutting the mustard with regard to its actual trade performance in maintaining market share. New Zealand is a case in point. New Zealand is niche market exporting to a great deal of Asia, south Asia, greater Asia and the Middle East, in a way which is taking the fight to our products more than I care to admit. New Zealand has of course done a great deal of industrial relations reform, taxation reform and waterfront reform and is extremely competitive in traditional Australian markets. I acknowledge that New Zealand has been out there securing market share, increasing market share in these dynamic economies of greater Asia and indeed right over in the Middle East. There is always a need to be cautious when giving anecdotal evidence and comment on matters relating to trade. Nevertheless, it has to be said that it is disappointing to walk into supermarket after supermarket in the Middle East to find that it is New Zealand product which is up in lights, New Zealand dairy product which is dominating the shelves and being given the priority. You then have to search for the Australian product around the comer at the bottom of the next shelf in a way which is a matter of very real concern. So there can be no complacency with Australia's trading effort. The coalition does not oppose the amendments before this chamber but I make the point that more work needs to be done with regard to Austrade, with regard to EMDG, and more work needs to be done to ensure that Australia maintains its market share in these growing Asian economies because we have been slipping behind in terms of market share in Indonesia, Malaysia and other Asian countries. 1476 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 Let me make one final point. I recognise that the government has been attempting to bolster its trading efforts to the Asian-Pacific region of the world. I want to remind the government that that ought to be done as an effort additional to all other trading efforts, not in place of them. For example, there is eastern Europe, which I know is of interest to some members as a potential expanded trading area for Australia, southern Europe and the North American markets. We should be opening up markets in South America and the Indian rim, which itself is an area of great potential. I fully support efforts to bolster our trading performance and increase our market share into the Asian countries particularly, the ASEAN countries, northeast Asia, south Asia and India and the Middle East. That should all be additional to our trading efforts in other regions in the world. Australia is a trading nation. By and large, it can be proud of its efforts. It can be proud of the decision taken in 1957 by John McEwen, minister for trade in the government of the day, to jump the gun and open up a trade treaty with Japan. At the time, this was done to the bitter opposition of the RSL but he showed real leadership in putting the framework approach and the facilitation that is government's role with regard to trade between Australia and Japan. This event in the 1950s underpinned huge developments such as Queensland coal, Western Australian iron ore and a raft of other activities and led to Japan being Australia's largest trading partner today. I would add that Australia and Indonesia must not be distracted by those elements which would seek to jeopardise a normal bilateral relationship and a warm bilateral relationship between our two countries. Indonesia is our largest neighbour. It is food for thought that those elements here in Australia which pursue certain agendas-and I respect their right to demonstrate, even their right to demonstrate this day-have led to the circumstance where it is now 19 years since the president of our nearest neighbour has visited this country. That in itself has a spill-over effect on the dynamic of the bilateral relationship and the underpinning of the trading effort of private enterprise in both directions between Australia and Indonesia. I am delighted that the Vice-President of Indonesia is visjting Australia at this time. I believe that, if the President of Indonesia finds himself able to visit Australia after this long gap, that too would be greatly appreciated. WhilstI do not approve for one moment of all that has happened in relation to East Timor over the years, I recognise the circumstances of the viewpoint of the government and the coalition with regard to East Timor overall. I say that Australia and Indonesia must have a strong bilateral relationship underpinned by a wide degree of contact, not just in the political realm-and recently senior ministers visited Canberra-not just in the business realm, with the further development of business council contact between Australia and Indonesia; but also in the cultural realm and right across the spectrum. Our two countries in this comer of the world have much to gain from a purposeful bilateral relationship underpinning expanded trading for the better standard of living of people both in Indonesia and in Australia. The coalition is not then opposed to the amending bill before the House, but I do stand by my comments of concern over the efficiency of Austrade and the need continually to amend its parent legislation. Development Grants Amendment Bill of 1994. This bill makes a number of minor technical amendments, which I will come to later. I would first like to make some comments on the scheme itself. The Export Market Development Grants Act of 1974 contains provisions which govern the method of application and eligibility for grants, a list of claimable export oriented
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Griffin (Corinella) (10.55 A.m.)
theText: We are here today to debate the Export MarketThursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1477 expenditure, and mechanisms for the review of decisions, the recovery of overpayments and the termination of grant entitlements. The export market development grants or EMDG scheme, which is administered under that act, provides taxable cash grants of up to $250,000 per annum-$500,000 for approved trading houses-and is based primarily on expenditure incurred by an Australian person or company seeking to create or expand exports of their products in overseas markets. Provided a person has incurred at least $30,000 of eligible expenditure in a grant year, that person will be entitled to a grant. A grant is calculated at 50 per cent of eligible expenditure after the first $15,000. Claimants who have received eight or more grants are not allowed to receive further grants, and claimants who have received at least two prior grants are subject to a performance test which is assessed against export earners. Eligible expenditure includes such things as up-front marketing costs, travel expenses, special promotional literature and overseas representation. The Australian Trade Commission, Austrade, which administers the EMDG scheme, considers the main benefits of the scheme to include the points that grant funding is guaranteed by legislation, the grant is cash in hand, and the grant directly supports the majority of expenditure categories likely to be incurred by an exporter. The EMDG scheme has been successful. It was a scheme which was first established 20 years ago by the Whit lam Labor government. The results achieved by programs such as EMDG, both in Australia and overseas, prove that governments can forge partnerships of mutual benefit with enterprises and, in doing so, can create jobs and a more positive export environment. In 1992-93, Austrade received 2,473 EMDG claims with a value of $181 million for the 1991-92 grant year. This compared with 2,002 EMDG claims with a value of $143 million for the 1990-91 grant year. Around 96 per cent of the EMDG claims in 1991-92 were processed by Austrade before 30 June 1992. In the 1993 financial year, the EMDG scheme assisted 3,250 enterprises seeking export markets by providing about $195 million in taxable grants. These grants helped reimburse the marketing and promotional expenses of firms which are trading in some of the world's most competitive markets, in particular in Asia. The number of claimants last year was up by 31 per cent on the previous year. This indicates that more Australian companies are taking up the export challenge and looking for export opportunities to expand their businesses. The EMDG scheme has been successful, and this was confirmed recently in an evaluation report entitled 'Helping to meet the export challenge'. As the report shows, most EMDG claimants-some 70 per cent-are small to medium sized firms: those with less than $5 million in turnover a year, exports of less than $1 million, and/or fewer than 26 employees. This is consistent with the findings of the 1993 Australian Manufacturing Council-McKinsey report into manufacturing exporters and the LEK service export study. Both studies report a trend towards smaller, innovative enterprises taking up the call to export. The number of service companies claiming EMDG is growing, and is currently at 45 per cent of all grants; with manufacturers at 37 per cent, traders 15 per cent and primary producers three per cent. However, the McKinsey report also highlighted the fact that there remains a real challenge to further increase the number of Australian manufacturers who are exporting. It is found that up to 90 per cent of Australian manufacturing companies do not export to any significant extent. 1478 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 One of the more pleasing findings of the EMDG evaluation is that enterprises receiving grants have a higher commitment to exporting, in terms of employment and investment in export activities, than non-EMDG participants. On average, about half the employment of EMDG recipients is export-related. EMDG also plays an important role in encouraging recipients to seek out new export markets. Research shows the EMDG claimants actually increase their own spending on export market promotion by more than the value of their grant. This additional spending and activity, according to the evaluation committee, results in more exports. A very important point is that the typical 'mature' EMDG exporter generates additional exports of up to 15 to 25 times the value of the grant received. In other words, for every dollar that EMDG provides to mature exporters, an additional $15 to $25 is generated in export income. This is certainly good news in terms of the balance of payments and, most importantly, in terms of jobs. Important as it is, the EMDG scheme is only one small aspect of a complex array of policies and programs in, for example, education, training and science; macroand micro-economic management; and trade diplomacy and facilitation. The government's basic domestic trade industry strategy has been, and continues to be, to ensure that these policies work together to provide an economic environment that will enable Australian industry to be competitive and to maximise our export performance. The government's white paper on employment and growth, Working Nation, represents the next step. It contains measures to promote research and innovation, to improve access to finance and capital, to encourage investment, to reduce the administrative burden of government regulations, to enhance labour force flexibility and to improve the skills base of the nation. Most of the measures announced in Working Nation will be of particular benefit to small and medium-sized businesses, because that is where the potential for jobs and new growth is greatest. One particular set of issues that I want to mention briefly is aimed at strengthening the integration of trade and industry policy and program delivery. At the policy level, the Board of Industry, Trade and Investment, comprising the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) and the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), has been established to coordinate the development of strategies for trade and investment promotion, export facilitation and industry development. One of the government's primary concerns is to ensure that industry development and trade facilitation programs are delivered to industry and business effectively and seamlessly, with the maximum of impact and at the least cost to the taxpayer and the minimum of inconvenience to business. The government also announced in Working Nation the extension of the EMDG scheme for a further five years, thereby providing assistance to, ultimately, about 5,000 exporters a year. Its expansions provide export marketing assistance to single service tourism operators and assistance for offshore marketing activities by providing low interest finance through ITES, the international trade enhancement scheme, for a further four years at $50 million a year. Regarding the amendments themselves that are contained within this bill, the question arises of joint venture and consortia and trading houses, which are limited to a lifespan of three years unless they are renewed. Currently, once approved, a JVC or TH can exist forever, as long as it continues to meet the original eligibility criteria. The three-year lifespan introduces an automatic review every three years to ensure that the JVCs meet changing market and government requirements. Austrade is also able to respond appropriately to any new Thursday,22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1479 considerations that may arise. If the joint venture is continuing to meet the criteria in the guidelines, it would be expected that re-approval would be automatic. JVCs are limited to a maximum of five grants. Currently, they are treated in the same way as independent claimants are, and may claim up to eight grants. JVCs are generally project specific, with a time duration of less than eight years. It was never intended that they be eligible for eight grants, and it is inconsistent with the nature of them, particularly as members are able to claim up to eight grants independently. The joint venture provisions give companies additional access to EMDG. Austrade would expect that, after five years, companies would have had time to develop the capacity to claim as individual claimants. They also believe that to give companies potentially 16 years in the scheme through the operation of the joint venture provisions is excessive. There has also been an extension in the time allowed for Austrade to seek information in relation to an application for an approved JVC or TH status from 30 days to 60 days. Austrade has found that, with the rush of claims at the end of the claim year, the existing 30 days is often not enough time to analyse what information may be needed to assess an application. This extension of time will allow for better decision making. If an application is complete, Austrade will be required to give an answer within 90 days, as is currently the case. If applications are lodged well in advance of the claim, Austrade will be able to deal with the matter more expeditiously. Austrade's experience is that neither of these assumptions can be relied on. The extension of time from 120 days-that is, the existing 30 days plus 90 days-to 150 days, being the extension of 60 plus 90, is a maximum only. It is expected that the vast majority of well prepared applications will be dealt with well within the time limits. Austrade may also apply new ministerial guidelines to existing JVCs and THs. There is currently conflicting legal opinion about whether Austrade can apply new ministerial criteria to an approved JVC or TH and cancel them if they do not comply. This section clarifies the intention and will enable Austrade to ensure that JVCs continue to meet government objectives. The overseas visits allowance is calculated on a daily basis under this new proposal. EMDG currently allows $200 per day as claimable expenses while on an overseas trip that is primarily for business purposes. However, Austrade is obligated to reimburse all the days of a trip where the purpose of the trip is primarily for business promotional purposes, including recreation days, and cannot reimburse business promotional days where that trip was not primarily for business. This amendment will allow Austrade to reimburse those days primarily devoted to business promotion to the exclusion of non-promotional days. There is also a provision for the establishment of a framework for a consultant accreditation scheme. About 50 per cent of EMDG claims are prepared by consultants. Austrade is working with consultants to lift claim preparation standards but considers that a formal legislative scheme may be necessary if consultants are not responsive to cooperative efforts. This is an important part of the government's overall approach to industry policy and to trade policy as a whole. We have here a scheme which facilitates and assists small and medium-sized firms, particularly, to expand and develop export markets overseas, not only to Asia but throughout the world to a number of the locations mentioned by the previous speaker, the honourable member for Farrer, the Leader of the National Party( Mr Fischer). The scheme has to be seen as part of an overall integrated program by government to assist business. The government does not believe that we can do it all by ourselves and it would be crazy to suggest that that was the case. We have a range of businesses and industries 1480 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 throughout Australia which have the capacity and the potential to expand into international markets throughout the world and to develop a much better trading base for Australia. We have a responsibility, as a government, to assist that. Programs such as the export access program, and the broad changes that have come into effect out of the white paper process, will assist many finns to address these sorts of issues, in terms of their forward planning in investment and markets. The bill helps to finetune this legislation and this scheme to make it even more effective. As I said, it is a scheme that has been expanding regularly over the last few years. It is a scheme which is held in good standing by industry, and it is a scheme which does the job of encouraging export marketing throughout Australia to all over the world. I commend the bill to the House. I note that it has support from both sides of the chamber and I wish it a speedy passage and that the changes have a speedy effect. Market Development Grants Amendment Bill. We believe it makes a number of worthwhile changes to the current act. The purpose of the amendment is to extend the period for consideration for approved joint venture and consortium and approved trading house applications. I will not go through it all because it has pretty well all been said before, but I will pick out a few points from the Auditor-General's report. My colIeague the member for Farrer, the Leader of the National Party( Mr Tim Fischer), stated earlier this year that he was concerned that the export scheme was drifting and called for the government to respond promptly. This bill sets in place the mechanisms for that drifting to stop. I come to the issue of the exporters of Australia. We alI understand that the $150 million to $250 miIlion that is involved in this scheme is but a drop in the bucket. When we think of the postwar period and the opportunities for stable trade, I suppose we must all welcome that. When we look at the opportunities in Asia, Europe, the US, South America, India, Africa, the Commonwealth of Independent States-the old Russia-and Eastern Europe, I guess it is fair to say that we have only started on this great journey of trade. It is acknowledged, overwhelmingly, that our EMDGs, as a fraction of our total exports are but a fraction of the full sum. It is more a matter of our culture. The percentage of enterprises within Australia which are currently exporting is very small. As I keep saying, we have only just started this journey. My electorate produces something like 50 per cent of South Australia's exports, so all my life I have been aware of the world trade situation. I suppose, as a farmer, one grows up understanding what exports are all about. In terms of incentive and the overalI picture for exports in Australia, I could talk all day about what we could and should do. But we are here today just to talk about the EMDGs. I refer briefly to employment. I complimented the member for Fraser( Mr Langmore) this morning when I saw him at a parliamentary committee meeting. In his book, Work for All, is a commitment that, as a country, we have forgotten how to target. Whilst the member for Fraser and I would differ on how we find jobs for alI Australians, I think he and I would be totally united in that target. I can only say that every piece of energy that I can muster will go into ensuring that this country enables every Australian to have a job. Exports are critical to that and, if anyone saw the former Senator Walsh's comments last night on Lateline, he has got a few pretty good suggestions for us in that area. He suggests that we just let the mining industry get on with the job and we will do ourselves, as a country, a lot of good.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Wakelin (Grey) (11.10 A.m.)
theText: Of course, the coalition does support the ExportThursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1481 I have made criticisms before about EMDGs. This is only a small point, I guess, but I think it is important to register it again. We do have a restriction in terms of the definition in the act in that an Australian person or company seeking to create or expand exports of their products in overseas markets may, provided the person has incurred at least $30,000 of eligible expenditure in a grant year, be entitled to a grant and the grant is calculated at 50 per cent of eligible expenditure after the first $15,000. I think this is very important. I would like to see those amounts lowered so that they may be picked up, and I think they would be picked up. I know many people who are interested in exporting, who would never, particularly in their initial sortie, spend that sort of money. It is a general criticism that I have made in the past and I will continue to make it. I am sure there will be criticisms from the administrators about the difficulty of administering so many claims and all that sort of thing but I cannot emphasise strongly enough that, if we want to be a country that offers full employment, if we want to be a country that maximises opportunity and its potential, then this is small beer to the small person in Australia, to the battlers in Australia who, particularly on their first trip, should be able to be picked up more easily than the current situation provides. I will conclude by simply saying that I welcome the audit office's recommendations, the improved accountability to parliament, the rationalisation of the strategic planning structure, the improved responsiveness, the improved quality of claims and control measures and optimisation of management planning and controls. Of course, Austrade accepts all these recommendations. Working Nation also had a number of changes to the export market development grant scheme and now it has extended the scheme to single service tourism operators to recognise the contribution of tourism to our exports. Of course, that is not before time. It also legislated to extend the export scheme for a further five years. In conclusion, there is nothing more important to this country-to its economic future-than exports. There is nothing more important to the well-being of our place in this region than developing stronger trading links and stronger exporting capacities. We have every reason in the world to do this. The Leader of the National Party spoke about our links with Indonesia. It cannot be overemphasised how important that is. At times, we are tardy in some of our trade dealings with people overseas. I think that is an area where we really need to lift our game. With those few words, I am quite happy to support the bill and I know that it will enhance the ability of Australians to access export markets. Grants Amendment Bill and we have heard a lot of the detail about the bill from previous speakers. I will not waste the time of the committee by going over that detail again. Perhaps it is worth mentioning briefly that this scheme is there to make sure that Australian businesses can get into export markets. It provides them with assistance in a variety of ways. The amounts can be quite significant and there are controls on how the money is spent, how it is accounted for and so on. What this bill is aiming to do is to make some modifications to that basic bill, to give more flexibility in some respects. It also aims to tighten up the rules of accountability and to target better the way that the money is spent. As I said, I am not going to go through all the detailed amendments. I am certainly not going to talk about the number of previous claims because it seems to me that one of the problems with bureaucracy these days is that we worry about the number of claims and the
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Nugent (Aston) (1l.l8 A.m.)
theText: We are talking about the Export Market Development1482 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 amount of dollars but we do not perhaps give enough time and attention to whether the scheme is carrying out the objectives for which it was established. Recently, I had the good fortune to be overseas. I looked at a number of things that other countries do and I had the opportunity to talk to Australians in those countries who were trying to do business there. I was able to look at things from a practical, on the ground, point of view. In particular, I spent time in Thailand, Singapore and Indonesia within the last two or three months looking at some of those sorts of issues. When an Australian business decides to go overseas, there are a number of problems. People face the language problem, they have got to learn all about the legalities, and quite often they need networks and contacts. They also have to look at the different cultural approach. Those things can take time. For example, just about everybody who has done business in Indonesiaand officials at the Australian embassy-will tell you that if you have not got contacts in the local community you really are not going to get much business done in Indonesia. It does not matter whether you are selling food, vehicles, or any other sort of product. It takes time to establish those contacts and time equates quite often to cost. The cost is, obviously, not just putting out brochures. There is also the cost of the travel, maintaining offices and people, hotel bills, and all those sorts of things. We are talking about cost, time, contacts, and local knowledge that it is so important to have. Unfortunately, too, many of our companies in this country are small, and, because we have had such a highly protected environment for so many years, an awful lot of them are not used to having to get out and compete in the cold, hard world. Many of our bigger companies do have those resources and are well experienced, but a lot of our small to medium-sized enterprises, colloquially known as SMEs, do not have that experience and they need assistance from schemes such as the EMDG scheme and others. One of the most common complaints I have heard from Australian companies is that processing tends to be slow, that there is not enough flexibility, and that we ought to be looking at new ways to help business. The coalition supports this particular bill-there is no question about that-but we would like to see much more being done; not only under this scheme but also under other schemes. The Prime Minister( Mr Keating) and others all agree in principle that Asia is important to this country's future, yet when we talk to people in Singapore and Indonesia all too often they tell us that their orientation is actually north. They are looking at going into China, South-East Asian areas and India. Although they recognise the importance of us to them, and vice versa, in many different ways, their major orientation is not down here. Therefore, we are always going to have a real battle to get ourselves established in those markets. That means that we have to get more of our smaller and medium-sized companies exporting overseas, and it means that we have to provide them with expertise and assistance to do that. I am not so sure that we are innovative enough. We need to look at a number of new options, particularly when we come to dealing with bureaucracy. We have got to look much more at setting up one-stop shop arrangements. In Singapore, for example, where I visited the Economic Development Board, the Institute of Standards and Industrial Research and the National Science and Technology Board, the government gets heavily involved in facilitating the process. It even pays for sending people overseas for training and gets actively involved in stimulating activity to get companies not only developing products, but also getting into overseas markets. The Singaporean government Thursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1483 is very heavily involved in setting up markets in Indonesia and India-it has big establishments in Bangalore in India-and it is doing similar things in China. Having made that heavy commitment to getting their businesses off the ground overseas, and then their marketing efforts, they apply quite rigorous disciplines in return on the companies, probably much more severe and rigorous disciplines than we do. For example, whereas this scheme is effectively on a dollar for dollar basis up to certain limits, in Singapore the company has to contribute three or four dollars for every dollar of government expenditure. Companies have to payout the money before they can claim it back-it is not a cash in hand activity. Also, in most cases the government will look to take some share of the profits, some form of royalty, or whatever, as a result of successful activity which the government may have sponsored. It seems to me that that probably helps in terms of their providing that revenue base, at a governmental level, for doing further things for other companies. In Indonesia, for example, where I had quite an extensive and good briefing, the embassy were very clear in their view that schemes such as the DIFF scheme were very poorly administered. I remember that two or three years ago, when I was a member of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, this parliament looked at the boatbuilding industry and particularly at the aluminium boatbuilding industry. We have a very thriving industry for catamarans, luxury launches, ferries and those sorts of things, and we export a lot of those products overseas. The constant refrain that one hears from Australian industry is that there is a lack of adequate financing from government sources, a lack of adequate support in terms of the quality of the Austrade representation, and a lack of adequate help with promotional activity and so on. A lot of those companies are small start-up companies that are going to be very successful but, in their formative stages, they do indeed need much more help and support. It is necessary to help those export industries. The measures that have been proposed in the legislation before the Committee are sensible, and we do support them, but the government does indeed need to look at fresh initiatives and I urge it to do so. discussion of the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill. The Working Nation statement on 4 May 1994 by the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) included a package of measures that were designed to boost Australia's export efforts. The Prime Minister announced that the export market development grants scheme would be extended for five years. Furthermore, in this legislation, the scheme is being expanded to extend eligibility to single service tourism operators and to include departure tax and visa fees as eligible expenditure. Total expenditure under the scheme will expand from $231 million to $290 million in 1997-98. A number of technical amendments are also introduced. Broadly, these allow better management and control of approved joint ventures and consortia and approved trading houses, give a greater promotional focus to payments for overseas travel expenditure, and provide Austrade with the power to introduce and administer the scheme of accreditation for export grants consultants. An important element of the government's policy is to assist individual Australian firms to gain access to export markets and to increase their market share. Many enterprises that are currently exporting or intending to export will benefit by the continuation of the EMDG scheme. To qualify, exporters must have eligible export revenue of less than $25 miIIion in the year of claim and must have incurred $30,000 in eligible expenditure. Many of our small to medium-sized enterprises qualify under these conditions.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Peter Morris (Shortland) (11.26 A.m.)
theText: I am pleased to participate in this1484 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 Grants of 50 per cent of eligible expenditure are available for overseas promotional activities such as market research and development, representation and advertising, for the cost of participating in overseas exhibitions, fares, departure taxes, visa fees, et cetera, and for the cost of bringing agents or buyers to Australia when promotion of export sales is the objective. The grant is aimed at encouraging enterprises to research and develop overseas markets for goods, specified services, industrial rights and know-how which are substantially of Australian origin. The maximum grant is $250,000 each year, and a minimum of $30,000 in eligible expenditure must be incurred first, as the threshold level, as I mentioned earlier, by the claimant company in order to be able to gain assistance under EMDG. I tum briefly to the regional picture of the Hunter, where the three members now in this Committee room, the honourable member for Newcastle ( Mr Allan Morris), the honourable member for Lyne( Mr Vaile) and I, are all domiciled. With a little bit of stretching and flexibility, that almost includes you, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, since you were born there: you are part of our region. More and more firms from the Hunter are seeking world markets for their expertise and products. This is really quite a dramatic change for the smaller to mediumsized enterprises in the Hunter, in that they are taking advantage of the assistance our government is offering. The extension of the EMDG scheme is an important part of that assistance. The scheme is being utilised by regional firms involved in such diverse industries as boatbuilding, packaging, light and heavy engineering, wine and software. I am not suggesting to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that wine and software go together! More and more small to medium enterprises are discovering markets other than their traditional domestic markets. It is so often the problem in regions that firms develop, are comfortable within their own regional market and domestic market, and do not go beyond that region. So the move from a domestic regional market to a national market, and beyond, to an overseas market, is indeed a step that is long overdue. It is something that this legislation will help encourage. The export market development grants scheme increases access and flexibility, which is designed to assist small to medium enterprises in the Hunter region. The government's overseas representation has been reinforced in recent years. A major part of the work of Australia's overseas posts, particularly Austrade, is to assist Australian firms to take advantage of trade and investment opportunities. Australian firms-Hunter firms-are developing new skills, new processes and better products, and they are tapping into markets that they could only dream of in the past. In the Hunter an important partnership between government and industry has resulted in the establishment of the Industry Development Centre at Callaghan ncar the University of Newcastle. The Industry Development Centre provides a one-stop shop or a single contact point to assist exporters and potential exporters to get ready to take on overseas markets. It acts as an encouragement program and helps demystify the culture that one should sell only in one's own domestic market. The IDC also provides a link between industry and commerce and the University of Newcastle. It provides accommodation to the university's consulting and marketing group, relationships with the university's Centre for Industrial Controlled Science. It is promoting the culture that is Hunter: that it will win because it is the best. It has the best price, it delivers Thursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1485 on time, it has an industrial relations attitude which enables the cost levels and time demands of customers to be met on a competitive basis. This partnership adds to the government's assistance to industry and commerce in many areas. One of these is best practice. The Australian Centre for Best Practice is headquartered in the Hunter for a very good reason; Hunter firms were among the first to realise that to succeed they must get it right the first time. In other words, there had to be quality, consistency in quality, minimisation of rejects and delivery on time. Hunter firms realised that they had to get it right the first time; they had to do it right and do it once. That gives the result that the customer wants and it keeps cost levels down. Hunter firms are benchmarking with and are being benchmarked by leading international firms. The export market development grants scheme provides a most useful tool to all businesses but especially to the small and medium-sized businesses. It enables these firms to explore for themselves the market they believe will benefit their business. The scheme provides financial incentives in the form of taxable cash grants based on eligible expenditure to promote export sales. It focuses on promotional activities-that is, it generally does not assist in the general establishment of business or product development. The grant is a cash grant. The EMDG scheme directly supports many expenditure categories likely to be incurred by an exporter. It is an open access scheme encompassing all goods made in Australia plus a range of services covered in the act. It covers, as I mentioned earlier, industrial property rights and know-how. It provides special provisions to enable joint ventures, industry groups and consortia to expand their activities. It has special provisions to assist first-time claimants. To qualify for the scheme, applicants must be Australian residents and be the owners of eligible goods, services, property rights or know-how. Also, as I mentioned earlier, applicants have to have incurred $30,000 in eligible expenditure within the grant year. Similarly, in that respect, they need to have received fewer than seven previous EMDG grants-except in the case where there is a new market to be tapped or opened up. They need to have eligible export earnings of less than $25 million in the year of claim. Of course, the successful business will utilise the other excellent services provided by Austrade. Austrade is able to provide export counselling to assist a company to get ready to export. It is able to provide counselling on what strategies there are for entering international markets. A business can find specialist help to enable it to take that first step. So in Austrade's 70 overseas posts, experts provide on-the-spot information and assistance. Austrade provides a range of market research and analysis services to help companies assess market conditions and potential for their products. When the company's representative visits a potential market overseas, possibly because of an export market development grant, Austrade can provide help in arranging itineraries and appointment schedules. An Austrade officer can accompany the representative and can assist with advice and communications. The scheme covered by the legislation is administered by Austrade, as are the international trade enhancement schemes. The bill also expands EMDG grants to provide export marketing assistance to single-service tourism operators to recognise the significant contribution of the tourism industry to export growth. Whilst tourism is our largest export earner, it has a lot of potential within the Hunter region; there is a lot to be gained there and a lot to be developed. If anything, tourism in the Hunter is in its infancy stage in that respect. Between 1978 and 1985, members of the tourism industry were eligible to receive EMDG grants. From 1985 to 1987, we changed the name of the scheme to the tourism overseas 1486 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 promotion scheme. In 1987, in Sir Humphrey land, assistance to the scheme was ended in that period of financial stringency. In 1990, the EMDG scheme became available for tourism operators but in a limited way. If an operator provided a single service-for example, an hotel or a car hire or an attraction like Dreamworld-that operator could not qualify. What the bill before us does is recognise the importance of all in the stream of tourism and it restores that assistance to that single service tourism operator. In dealing with that whole service sector, I believe there is a lack of effort in many parts of Australian business and on behalf of the government generally in exploiting the opportunities for service. Service operates both ways: it is a service sector in delivering a product; it is a service sector in bringing in an imported product. It is a two-way process that covers a range of industries and a range of activities that really have not been developed in this nation to anything like the extent they could be. I am looking at the LEK report on services. Page 15 says: Australia's most successful service exports include tourism, which comprises about 60% of service exports ($7.8 billion in 1993) and education, which in 1993 clocked up $1.2 bill ion ... Most of the 28 service industry categories canvassed have a low ratio of exports to domestic sales ... Indeed, only 1.2 % of all Australian service companies are involved in export. This represents only 5% of total services capability. In other words, 95 per cent of Australia's services capability is not involved in export. As I said, it is a two-way process. We do not need to build a coalmine; we do not need to make steel; we do not need to disturb the environment; we do not need to offend our neighbours or residents or anyone else to be in the service sector. That service sector, particularly in relation to transport and what swings off that I will come to that in a few moments-has a massive area for growth within Australia. There has to be a change in the culture in this city; there has to be a change in the culture of what I call ' Sir Humphrey land' which is this place, the people who lead departments, the people who are responsible for government purchases. We can look across this whole services sector to the Bevis report on government purchasing. I am looking at the page of the report dealing with the embedded services and the advice to government purchasing agencies covered in the Commonwealth procurement circular 90/9 of November 1990. That procurement circular tells Commonwealth officers: In complying with Commonwealth policy, and applying the concept of value for money, procurement officers should consider: . the cost of insurance and freight; and . the opportunity for QANTAS, Australian ship owners, local insurers, freight forwarders and other local suppliers to participate in these activities ... By recognising that insurance and freight costs can be significant in their own right, procurement officers may be able to achieve major savings in the cost of overseas procurements or indirect importation of supplies. But the committee found that the simple step of identifying the price of freight and insurance appears not to have been taken in the majority of cases. The frequency of importing product on a free on board basis-f.o.b., whereby the purchaser arranges the freight insurance-does not appear to have been substantially altered. The document goes on to say: In 1991 a survey of Government Business Enterprises and Statutory Marketing Authorities by the Insurance and Freight Working Party identified that, while agencies imp0l1ed 21.4 % of goods on an FOB basis, they exported 36.3% on an FOB basis thus giving overseas suppliers nearly 70% more access to activity. Thursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1487 In other words, they have got a 'sell f.o.b.' mentality, whereby they leave it to the buyer on the other side of the world to arrange the transport, the insurance and the freight. All of the service sector is just handed over on a platter. There may be some reasons, in some parts of trade, that make it difficult to get on to a cost insurance freight basis, whereby the seller is responsible for arranging cost insurance freight. We get some of that benefit. But there is a vast potential there that is not even being explored, because of the culture in this place. When the government's own agencies-which combine to be one of the largest single purchasers in this nation-do not have that culture, do not follow that thought process and do not follow Commonwealth procurement guidelines, it is a pretty poor model for saying to the private sector, 'We think you should be selling CIF. We think you should be buying free on board.' Take, for example, importing components for reprocessing for the Holden car. We import all of the engines. We do not buy on an f.o.b. basis; we buy on a cost insurance freight basis, where all of the transport, consolidation in the states and insurance is arranged by the seller. The seller gets all of that benefit. We have to change that. If we go to the practice whereby we import products for reprocessing, consolidation or incorporation in products that are subsequently exported, we are losing all of that service sector. But we generally do not even try to get it. Let me give you an example, Mr Deputy Speaker. You will relate to this one. In the debate about coal, the coal unions are saying, quite rightly, that there should be a greater effort on the part of Australian sellers to get a better price. They suggest we do it the Japanese way, and out-organise the Japanese. I use this because it is an easy example. But the Japanese want open market forces to operate in determining the sale price of coal. Open market forces mean you have to have open market access. It is very simple. If there are to be open market forces, there has to be open market access. When we look to the north of Australia, Japan is buying coal on an open market price development process. But on the west coast of Australia, the same Japanese steel mills buy our iron ore. Our marine insurers are competitive, but they cannot get into that market to insure the iron ore, because that marine insurance market is reserved for Japanese insurance companies. Yet the freight is sold similarly. Everything goes out fo.b. If we are looking at growth in service income-growth in invisible exports; that is really what it is-whether it be on imports coming in or on exports going out, in those cases we have to change the culture of Australian companies. But, most of all, in the first place we have got to change the culture of government servants and government agencies. We will move on and look at exports. We export Holden engines. Millions of dollars worth of Holden engines are exported, but the V6, which comes from North America and goes into the Commodore, is consolidated in North America. All of the parts of the components come together and are brought in, as I understand it, on a CIF basis, cost insurance freight. I am pleased to support the legislation. I think that it will do a great deal to help firms in our own Hunter region to improve their efforts abroad. I place particular emphasis on the opportunities in the service sector, and I hope that as time passes, we will be able to persuade more and more Australian firms that, when they are selling an Australian product, they should go to the trouble of saying, 'Have you thought about Australian insurance, have you thought about using Australian freight forwarders, have you thought about using Australian transport? In most of the cases, it involves shipping. There are many markets where we can be 1488 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 competitive. We have to be selective, but we can pick our mark, and if we can do that, then we are going to get a much better result for this country and a much better result on the current account deficit. Perhaps one day we will have a current account surplus. markets for export. That is something that both sides of the House would agree on. It is obviously important for the balance of payments, but it is also important for job and wealth creation. In my electorate of Leichhardt, exports are obviously a very important part of the local economy. The figures that are available-they are 1991 figures-show that the total value of commodities exported overseas from Far North Queensland was $610 million, which was 5.3 per cent of the value of commodities exported from the whole of Queensland, and 1.2 per cent of the value of Australia's merchandise trade. It is obvious that Far North Queensland plays a very big role in Australia's export markets, in potential as well as existing markets. It is interesting that the honourable member for Maribyrnong ( Mr Griffiths), the former tourism minister, is here, because tourism is a major export from the far north. It is actually the major export from Far North Queensland now, as the member would be aware, and it is a services export. I totally endorse the comments of the member for Short land ( Mr Peter Morris), who said that the export market and development scheme and other measures will expand into the tourism industry. The scheme is, of course, welcomed by the tourism industry, and by representatives of the tourism industry in my electorate. As I understand it, there were 3,200 claims for EMDG in 1993-94, and an expected payout of about $200 million. I think that is quite significant; it is obviously a scheme which is working. The purpose of the bill is to amend the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974, in order to extend the period for consideration of approved joint ventures in consortium applications and approved trading house applications. Other amendments provide for greater scrutiny of grant recipient activities. As members are now aware, the Export Marketing Development Grants Act contains provisions which govern the method of application and eligibility for grants, a list of claimable export oriented expenditure and mechanisms for review of decisions, recovery of overpayments, and termination of grant entitlements. The export marketing development grants scheme, the EMDG scheme, which is administered under the Export Marketing Development Grants Act 1974, provides taxable grants of up to $250,000 per annum and it is based primarily on expenditure incurred by an Australian person or company seeking to expand exports of products and overseas markets. Provided that people have incurred at least $30,000 of eligible expenditure in a grant year, they will be entitled to a grant. A grant is calculated at 50 per cent of eligible expenditure after the first $15,000. Claimants who have received eight or more grants are not allowed to received further grants, and claimants who have received at least two prior grants are subject to a performance test which is assessed against export earnings. Eligible expenditure includes such things as up-front marketing costs, travel expenses, special promotional literature and overseas representation. The Australian Trade Commission, Austrade, which administers the EMDG scheme, considers that the main benefits of the scheme include grant funding that is guaranteed by legislation. The grant is cash in hand, and the grant directly supports the majority of expenditure categories likely to be incurred by an exporter.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Dodd (Leichhardt) (11.46 A.m .)
theText: It is obvious that Australia has to develop furtherThursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1489 I have already given the 1992-93 figures. In 1991 there were 2002 EMDG claims to the value of $103 million. Obviously, the scheme is expanding, and becoming more popular and successful. I take the opportunity in this debate to talk about a major export success story in my electorate. I refer to the McKinsey report, Lead local compete global: unlocking the growth potential of Australia s regions, which has received a lot of attention in the House. It was a report for the Office of Regional Development in the Department of Housing and Regional Development. With regard to the Far North Export Group it says: Size is not a binding constraint to export, particularly when small businesses form collaborative networks. In Cairns, for example, business-led networks like the FNEG are forming to increase the international competitiveness of member enterprises. It goes on to say: Results for the group have been impressive. Rapid growth in exports is fuelling expansion in total sales. The FNEG is an association of over 20 companies which provides quality products and services to markets in Papua New Guinea, South-East Asia and the South Pacific. The FNEG was formed as a result of a northern region export promotion program held in Cairns and Townsville in 1992. This program was coordinated by Queensland DBIRD, the Queensland Premier's Department and the Australian Institute of Export. FNEG provides a coordinated central source of information to assist its members to access overseas markets for their products and services. FNEG members took part in two trade missions: one was in 1993 to Papua New Guinea with Austrade assistance, and there was another more recently to the Solomons. The strength of FNEG is that it is simple in structure and remains relevant to local Far North Queensland companies. It is an excellent vehicle for businesses interested in export but unable to allocate adequate time and effort to prepare for export. It provides a central point for coordinating overseas marketing and handling overseas enquiries. It provides marketing information and other matters of interest in a compact and accessible form. This enables local participating businesses to share information, market intelligence and ideas, improve their export performance and share market entry costs which might otherwise be prohibitive to an individual enterprise. The group also improves the ability of members to offer customers a broad range of products through the linkage of complementary power-all this while sharing the cost of market intelligence and R&D. I was please to visit some of the companies involved in this scheme with the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Regional Development and Housing( Mr Howe) very recently in Cairns. I know that the minister was impressed with the performance of that group. We visited the premises of Garozzo Agencies, Cairns Steel Fabricators, Shortland Oil Services, Northern Engine Reconditioning and Maunder Electrical Engineering. All the firms that we observed that day playa very vital and vibrant part in the far northern economy. Not only do they provide goods and services to the domestic market of Far North Queensland and other parts of Australia but they are also exporting into South-East Asia and the Pacific. Of course, in Cairns we are uniquely located to serve, in particular, the markets of South East Asia and the South Pacific. Everyone knows about the success of the Cairns airport. With all the planes that are coming in and out of Cairns not only is there capacity for tourism and personal travel but also we are able to export goods to South-East Asia and the South Pacific. 1490 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 All those firms that I mentioned are developing or have developed markets in South-East Asia and the Pacific through the assistance of this group. The FNEG is an obvious success story that the McKinsey report highlights, and I am pleased to highlight it in the parliament today. As I said, the Minister for Housing and Regional Development was very impressed with the group. I would thank especially Mac Thomson, who is the guiding person in this group, for arranging the trip and I thank all those people who gave us hospitality on that day. The thing that impressed me is that on that trip not only were we seeing businesses which were booming but also we were seeing the work force, people involved in manufacturing in my electorate. Of course, a lot of people in my electorate are involved in tourism, but I think it is very important for the future economy of the far north, the future economy of Australia, that we maintain a diversified economy and that there are manufacturing firms still in operation in regions like Far North Queensland. It was very heartening to see. Getting back more particularly to the substance of this bill before the Main Committee, it is interesting that there has been some criticism of the export market development grants scheme and I suppose criticism of the Australian government's policy towards trade. Professor Helen Hughes, who is someone on the free market end of the academic spectrum, has been critical of some of the government's policies. It is interesting to look at the performance of the export market development grants scheme and to see how successful it has been. I am not just saying this because I assert that it is a success story. The government obviously was concerned about some criticism of these sorts of schemes and conducted an evaluation by Price Waterhouse, with an independent econometric analysis by Ron Bewley, who is professor of econometrics and head of the department of economics at the University of New South Wales. The evaluation of the scheme said that it came out on top. Overall, the evaluation concluded that the scheme is effective in assisting Australian business. As I have already said, the success is shown in the fact that in 1993-94 there were 3,200 claims for EMDG grants, with an expected payout of $200 million. That speaks for itself. Businesses in Australia are going out there and applying for these grants. But it is interesting that the report that I referred to said that 70 per cent of these claims were from firms with less than $5 million in turnover, less than $1 million export or fewer than 26 employees. So not only are we assisting business in developing exports, we are assisting small business. I think it is unfortunate that the small business sector in Australia is one sector that does not acknowledge the contribution that this government has made, because in this and other schemes the government does assist small business. That statistical information shows that this scheme in particular not only helps the big end of town, as it were, it also helps small players. When we look at the success story that I have talked about with small business in Cairns and we look at the success story with this scheme all over Australia, it certainly does show that this government is providing the environment and the policies for export. The claimants for the scheme have high levels of commitment to exporting, with exporting accounting for an average 50 per cent of the employment investment. Again, that shows the success of this scheme, that it is not a question of hit and miss. It is not the case that claimants make claims, get some quick money from the government and do not have success stories. The success is shown in that figure, that 50 per cent of that employment investment is going into exporting activity. Thursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1491 It was very pleasing to see that, in the white paper, Working Nation, the government decided to extend the EMDG scheme for a further five years to extend the eligibility of EMDG grants to an expanded range of services, including single service tourism operators. This is obviously a very important initiative of the government and something that the tourism operators, as I said earlier, have been calling for, for some time. In the white paper, Working Nation, the government is responding to a clear demand from tourism operators and listening to the tourism industry. In conclusion, this scheme and the other schemes that the government has introduced in relation to encouraging exports have been a success. The government is proud of its record in this regard and I am pleased to support this legislation before this chamber. Question resolved in the affirmative. Bill read a second time. Motion (by Mr O'Keefe)-by leave-agreed to: That the bill be reported to the House without amendment. Report Debate resumed from 31 May, on motion by Mr Beazley: That the House take note of the paper. a few words on the report of the Access to Justice Advisory Committee entitled' Access to Justice'. It is an extensive report of some 500 pages. If the volume of the report were equalled by the significance of its content, it would be a weighty documen1 indeed. However, in any area there will inevitably be some matters with which we agree and others with which we disagree and, certainly, on looking through the report, I find that that is the position that I am in here. The concept of examining and identifying the degree to which access to justice is equally available is something that I think has total bipartisan support. It is a matter of very real significance and consequence. I am and have been for a long while concerned about the extent to which the mumbo jumbo, if you like, of the law tends to confuse rather than to reveal. It is also of concern to me that, according to people's social and economic strata in society, the opportunity they have to have their particular cases heard equitably, I believe, is prejudiced. There is also a problem with the legal aid system. This system is provided to give people access to legal advice but it does not always produce people whom I regard as having the same ability to present a case as those who can afford to provide their own counsel and their own legal advisers. This inequity in the system is unfortunate, as it is at the root of the problem of ensuring the equitable hearing of the matter. In this report, there is comment about the extension of legal aid. Obviously, there has to be a way to help people to have access to the law if they are unable to provide for their (')wn legal representation. I welcome the judgment of the High Court that puts an obligation on people receiving legal aid when it goes to that stage of justice. There are still impediments which are not addressed in this report for those who are beyond the economic means test level to receive legal aid, who are contending against litigants who have significant resources.
title: Representatives Main Committee

speaker: Mr Sinclair (New England) (12.02 P.m.)
theText: I am pleased to have the opportunity to say1492 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 Every member of parliament is aware of any number of cases where people are in a disadvantageous position against a larger corporation or organisation which has a lot of funds and those individuals find themselves disadvantaged. Some years ago, when I first became the Minister for Social Services, Hugh Roberton, who was then the member for the Riverina and was my predecessor in that portfolio, said to me, 'Every time you extend the means t-st, all you do is extend the borders of discontent.' How right that is with legal aid, because the people who are just outside the boundaries of legal aid often are as disadvantaged as the people just below the limit and, in many instances, they are denied the opportunity to pursue their case. That particular area is not adequately picked up in the report. Another recommendation in this report with which I am in disagreement is the question of robing. I know it is anachronistic to wear a wig and a gown and all that jazz, but one thing that does concern me is that there has to be a measure of impartiality in the law. I have been involved as a minister, unfortunately, on a range of occasions when members of the Family Court have been subjected to personal threats. One particular judge was killed. Judges who wear ordinary clothes are seen to be at one with the community. The law is not like that. The law has many inequities but we look towards people who are practising at law as having a professional capability. When surgeons are in an operating theatre, they wear their robes for reasons unrelated to status. They wear them because of hygiene and because of the extent to which they have to divorce themselves from the patient on whom they are operating. To my mind, in the same way, members of the legal profession need to be in some way distinguished from the person for whom they are acting, or whom they are prosecuting. While robing does not give them any greater legal capacity, it does, to a degree, distinguish them from the person they are prosecuting or defending, and there is an advantage in it. While I know all the arguments, and although I am not particularly keen in getting dressed up in my own wig and gown, I still recognise the advantage, in the processing of cases, of being able to wear something that does distinguish a person as being something different and having a different status. Having picked out those two areas of the report, there are a number of other recommendations with which I am in total agreement. For example, I think the idea of encouraging federal courts to develop court charters to specify performance standards is a very good idea. It is a good idea to continue the reform of procedures in both civil and criminal cases. In this respect, I would like to commend the work that has been undertaken by Murray Gleeson, the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of New South Wales. There are far too many delays in the legal process. Much of the delay is the result of court procedures. It is not because of the law itself; it is a matter of the way in which the processes require matters to be heard, considered and dealt with. I am sure, if we could expedite the law, that justice would be done in many instances-not only in criminal cases but also in civil cases. As members, many of us find ourselves in an impossible position on occasions with people who are subject to some sort of insurance claim. It is ridiculous that years after an event people are still waiting for the processing of their particular claim. There does need to be a lot more work done. Murray Gleeson is in the state supreme court in New South Wales. The report we are debating today was commissioned by the Attorney-General( Mr Lavarch) and the Minister for Justice( Mr Kerr) and, as a result, it applies to the Federal Court. It should apply right across the spectrum of justice. There has to be a way by which consideration of matters at a Thursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITTEE 1493 civil and criminal level can be expedited. Otherwise, a lot of people are going to be significantly disadvantaged. There is reference in the report to an area my wife Rosemary has been involved in. It is something that is also of interest, that is the use of television in court. There are two aspects to it. The first concerns the taking of evidence from children in child abuse cases. The Chief Magistrate in the Australian Capital Territory has done quite a lot of pioneering work in that respect, and I commend him for it. It is hard to know in what way and to what degree we can establish for children a fair and reasonable opportunity to give evidence without feeling that the strange environment to which they are subject in a courtroom in some way threatens them and means that their evidence is less than credible. Taking evidence from a child is always difficult, and the idea of having evidence taken from a child using a television camera has a great deal to be said for it. It is a process which should be adopted on a wider basis. It has much for which to be commended, and it is a process that we should look at on a wider base. The report refers to a somewhat wider subject, that is the experimental programming for televising court proceedings. I am not a great devotee of the results of television. There is obviously an advantage for all members in having their names and images out there being seen by people who are able to pass judgment on them, but, for the life of me, I do not see that debating within the chamber has benefited as a result. We are debating this in the Main Committee. There are about as many people here as there would be in the House itself, if we were down there. Debate should be a matter of trying to talk about a subject. On many subjects there is a great deal of unanimity across the parliament, but, where there is difference, there should be a genuine opportunity to present and to hear another point of view. When there is a television camera, everything is going out on the television screen, and, more often than not, people are concerned about who is going to be the end viewer. It is not a matter, therefore, of trying to persuade those who are in the room; it is a matter of trying to present a wider image. Television is intrusive and demands that people do things differently. All people need to do is look behind the Prime Minister( Mr Keating) in question time and they will see an array of pretty faces, well dressed in appropriate colours. faces, appropriately dressed, but the interesting point is that with television people are not necessarily looking at the verdict. I guarantee that any of the people here who were looking at television last night cannot remember very much of what was said, but can remember what a person looked like. Think of the people who are on the news. Sure, people who look at Days of Our Lives, or one of the soapies that get you in, get involved with the emotions of the subject, but that is different. Television is intrusive. It demands a different nature of performance, and it does not allow debate. It allows the image to be examined, not the substance, and that concerns me. To go to that extent in court is mad. It is difficult to maintain impartiality in our court process. We have a number of procedures which are designed to ensure there is equity between the two sides of a particular case. Once we go to the stage of having television in court, what we are going to do is have everybody out there passing judgment.
