speaker: Mr Sinclair
theText: Of course, Alan. That is the point. I too have behind me an array of pretty1494 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 Without wanting to go into the 0.1. Simpson case, demonstrably there it has all happened. No matter whether 0.1. Simpson is gUilty or innocent, he will never be able to have a fair trial. The result of that will be that when his defence counsel gets up in the court he will be able to say to the judge, 'How is it possible for my client ever to be gauged dispassionately by the members of the jury?' Looking at that case and at the television, and understanding the prejudiced way in which its reporting has been undertaken, there is no doubt that that comment is right. How on earth can a jury, after seeing the whole of the circumstances-all the trivia regarding his matrimonial ethics, matrimonial affairs, the titillation of the third party, and all the rest of it, all displayed in full glory-judge a matter like that dispassionately? Of course, it cannot. That is really the problem. Why on earth do people want an experimental program for televising court proceedings? The idea is bonkers, it does not have any validity, it is intrusive and it will prejudice justice. Anything that prejudices justice, to my mind, ought to be set aside. There are a few other things in the report that are quite good. The idea of presenting a report is good. Another report talked about a program for making criminal legislation clearer and more accessible. Part of the problem is not only making it accessible, but making it understandable. Any legalese is difficult to comprehend, but equally, it needs to be remembered that the simpler we make the law, the more we are going to pass the interpretation of the law over to the courts. We have to find, if we can, a balance between them. We define law in simple every day expressions, and over the years we pick up words and interpret them differently. Unless an explanation is given, the interpretation will depend on judgment of particular words. Again, I think we can prejudice justice. Make law accessible by all means; make law understandable by all means, but please be careful in rewriting law. The one thing in that sense that I would like to see the parliament pick up is a considered program for reviewing, revising and updating legislation. People who go into the parliament will know what we spend a lot of our time doing. If they have a look at the blue, they will see legislation listed. For example, Government Business-Orders of the Day on today's blue lists the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2). We get a new bit of paper each day. Usually it will not be as thick as what I have in my hand though sometimes it is much thicker. Every time legislation is amended we get more and more pieces of paper. We get one that is not too thick, one that is quite thick and about 10 others. Then, before we know where we are, we have got a great bundle of legislation, all of which we are supposed to be able to read, digest and understand. We are supposed to know where each amendment comes and how it applies. I do not think that it works. I would like to see the government adopt a program, to be put in place by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel. I think it would be better than the Attorney-General's Department. I would like to see the Office of Parliamentary Counsel have a designated group of people who are consistently charged with updating legislation. It takes time to do. I know, as minister for shipping and transport in days gone by, that the British merchant shipping act of 1894 was, unbelievably, the piece of legislation applicable to all maritime traffic in Australia, until not so many years ago. That was because trying to rewrite it in the Australian vernacular took so long; it took us about 10 years. Updating legislation is a good idea and I would like to see a few more people do something about it. Thank you for the opportunity to have a bit of a discussion. I have quite enjoyed it. (Time expired) Thursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMITIEE 1495 find the comments of the right honourable member for New England( Mr Sinclair) entirely appropriate, for those of us who enjoyed the practice of the law were, of course, aware of the faults of the law. We all understand that justice is a notion which involves questions of fairness and equity, representation and the right to be heard, yet those of us who have, fortunately or unfortunately, studied jurisprudence know that the philosophical notions of justice are indeed different. In fact, it is true that those of us who have, in our other lives, practised the law-and in my case I spent 10 years as a police officer as well-know that justice is always in the eye of the beholder: no matter what a court or a jury may find in a particular matter, those who are for will find it just if they win, and those who lose will find it unjust. The whole notion of justice is indeed nebulous and very difficult to define. Hence the report which we are taking note of in this chamber today-the access to justice report-has a lot in it which I can both agree and disagree with. Certainly, from what I read of it, here in Australia, I look at the American experience with great fear that we should ever go the same way. There is the example of the 0.1. Simpson trial. It will be almost impossible to find a jury which does not have a firm view on the guilt or innocence of 0.1. Simpson. Even here in Australia, people have made up their minds one way or the other that 0.1. Simpson is guilty or is not gUilty. How in the blazes is a system of justice going to operate when juries have been given so much biased media reporting, before the jury has even been detennined? I would be very fearful of any move in this country that would allow that sort of circumstance to arise. It is true that whilst I, on the government side, am not generally regarded as conservative, when it comes to the practice of law and the administration of justice I am indeed conservative. I am very wary of change for change's sake and very wary of change because the media, the electronic media, or the public generally, want it. I have seen a number of examples in my life where justice, in a philosophical sense, was not applied. One of my early experiences as a lawyer was to defend a person charged with murder. To this day, I do not know whether that person committed the murder or not. It was a rather famous case-R. v. Ratten. Mrs Ratten was shot on 7 May at 1 p.m. in 1970. Even today, many years later, I can still recall the exact time and date on which she was shot. Her husband, Leith Ratten, was charged with that murder. There was no doubt that he killed his wife. The question was whether it was an accident or whether it was premeditated-hence, murder. That case ultimately went to the Privy Council in England and was one of the very last matters that left Australia's jurisprudential system to be detennined by the Privy Council, the English system. I say that because justice is, indeed, a view. People can never say, in difficult cases, that they believe absolutely that a person is guilty or not guilty. Hence our system, rightly or wrongly, says that the Crown needs to carry the burden of proof and that that proof must be beyond all reasonable doubt; and, prior to that, the person must be accepted as innocent of that crime. I will oppose any change to this vehemently and strongly because, even under those pretty rigid rules, there is still potential for error. That is because jurors are human beings. They view people through their own prejudice; they view evidence through their own prejudice, as we all do as human beings. When there are 12 people they can, through their own prejudice, find guilt. However, on a better forensic examination, that guilt sometimes is not there. I speak as someone who has quite often questioned notions of justice. I speak as someone who has charged people with crimes, followed them through the system and seen

speaker: Mr Cleeland (Mcewen) (12.17 P.m.)
theText: May I say that, as I do on many occasions, I1496 MAIN COMMITTEE Thursday, 22 September 1994 them go to gaol. At the same time, as a lawyer, I have defended people who are charged and have, over that period, developed quite different notions of justice and the way our systems work. Without question, I most certainly oppose too much media access to our system. I have concerns about the victims of crime organisations springing up in this country. I would agree entirely that the victim of crime is often the last person in our processes. But people tend to forget that our system of justice is such that the state is the complainant; it is the state, the corporate structure, which is complaining about the conduct of others in criminal matters, not the victim. The victim's redress is in the civil jurisdiction-to seek damages and to seek other forms of remedy against the person who committed the crime. When the state is seen in two areas-not only to be enforcing behaviour through the criminal law but also to be, if you like, punishing in terms of monetary penalty to the victim-the two areas get rather confused and difficult. I know that, particularly in Melbourne and Victoria, the victims of crime organisations are now becoming critical organisations in the sense that they are insisting that governments move in ways in the justice system which I find quite fearful. I suppose I have seen some fundamental changes since I first started practising law in 1970. One of my great worries is the fact that, in Australian law schools today, there are as many undergraduates as there are practising lawyers in Australia. That is a most fearful thought because, since my days of entering practice, the number of practising lawyers has quadrupled. I can only speak of Melbourne and Victoria. Certainly, there is now a lawyer on every street corner in Melbourne and in Victoria. You cannot turn your back without finding a lawyer or a legal practice. Economics teaches us that, the more people there are seeking a source of income from a given field of income, the more prices rise or standards collapse as people are forced into doing things to gain an income source out of a fixed or limited field of income. A constituent who called me last week is the father of a young lady who had gone through a family law breakdown problem, a property settlement in the Family Court. His daughter had just received the bill from the legal firm. It was a complex matter in that the husband's family had a number of corporate structures where assets were rather difficult to trace-maybe deliberately so, maybe not. In any event, it was obviously a fairly complex property settlement. Nevertheless, the Family Court apparently ordered a property settlement of $145,000 to the custodial spouse, the wife, who had three children as well, and sent her a bill for $65,000. I do not find that justice, quite frankly. I have difficulties when, in that type of breakdown, the $145,000 is diminished by a legal bill of $65,000 so that the custodial spouse and the young children involved in that breakdown will undoubtedly be thrown back onto the public purse and seek further assistance because of the high cost of the legal system. There is that very famous case in New South Wales involving a lawyer, Mrs Foreman. I think we have all read about Mrs Foreman's tribulations before the Law Institute of New South Wales on a disciplinary procedure where, on a property settlement of some $540,OOO-again in the Family Court-her legal fees were in excess of the property settlement. Justice which is not affordable is justice which is denied. As a lawyer, I have to sit back and really query where the legal profession is going when with those kinds of legal charges people will be denied rights. My fear even now is that many people are not getting access to our judicial systems because they cannot afford lawyers. Thursday, 22 September 1994 MAIN COMMIITEE 1497 The Kennett government in Victoria, for example, has slashed $10 million from legal aid funding. Taking $10 million dollars from legal aid funding is quite severe. In my years of practice I found it impossible to get legal aid funding for people who were facing criminal charges in magistrates courts. It became increasingly difficult to get legal aid funding for matters in the Family Court. Now in Victoria it is just about the case that people get legal aid funding only for murders or the most severe crimes where prison is the appropriate penalty, and more and more ordinary people are being denied appropriate funding to gain access to justice. As I said, access to justice means ability to pay, ability to fund and ability to get access to the courtrooms. Increasingly in Australia the reality is that people are being denied that right because of financial difficulties. There are some proposals in this report which may assist in reducing the cost of legal representation. There is no doubt the legal profession has been fairly restrictive in the way it has conducted itself over a number of years. For example, in VictoriaI was admitted to practise as a barrister and a solicitor. That is, I had the right as a lawyer to appear before the Supreme Court and Magistrate's Court as a barrister. I also had the right to practise as a solicitor without appearing in courts; in fact, in my own career I appeared as both. When I practised in country areas I donned the garb and appeared in county courts and magisterial courts. When I went back to the city I practised generally only in magistrates courts and as a solicitor. When I was moved to practise in the state of New South Wales, much to my horror, I found that I was not entitled even to be called a barrister and a solicitor. It is a divided profession; that is, the bar is a completely separate legal profession from solicitors. In fact, my title in New South Wales as an admitted practitioner is as an 'attorney proctor and solicitor' of the state of New South Wales. As a Victorian admitted practitioner, when I appeared in the Supreme Court in Sydney to be admitted to practice I was not even referred to as a barrister and a solicitor because the reality that as a lawyer I could be a barrister and a solicitor was not recognised. So New South Wales still has a long way to go in recognising that today all lawyers are graduates from universities. There is no distinction between the legal training of those who call themselves barristers and those who call themselves lawyers, and it is an absolute nonsense to distinguish between people who are qualified in both areas of practice. Those at the bar, of course, say that they are the advocates, they are skilled at verbal appearances. I do not know about that. I am not a practising barristerI know in Victoria. Indeed, I have seen some abysmal performers in terms of advocacy in my career as a lawyer, and I have never understood why they say they are the orally skilled practitioners of the law. I think the rules of QC and junior are really a wank-how else can you describe them. Why should any person in a particular legal matter be forced to pay for the services of a QC and at the same time pay half the fee of the QC to a junior barrister, who inevitably does very little, in my experience, in such a trial? There is no doubt whatsoever that a large number of costs associated with access to justice are due to the antiquated notions of the legal practice in Australia. They are, of course, those which we inherited from the practice in Great Britain. It comes back, I guess, to the view that we in Australia should start to cast off some of those ancient British notions and develop our

After all, courts are about conflict. Be it in the civil jurisdiction or the criminal jurisdiction, it is a conflict between two people. If you are charged with a crime and the state says, 'You did this', you as the defendant say, 'No, I did not do this', so there is conflict, and we are resolving conflict through the judicial process. In the civil jurisdiction, too, that is really what it is all about. So we can reduce costs very largely by getting some of the archaic and anachronistic procedures we adopted from Britain and look for a mediation process and means of reducing cost and making access more readily available. In summary, there is much to recommend in this report but there is much which, frankly, I would have a great degree of difficulty in accepting. I do so, I just want to say that I trust that this matter wiIl continue to be on the agenda, as there are, I think, a number of members from both sides who stiIl wish to make a contribution in this debate and who for one reason or another are not available. I think part of the answer to that, and the member for McEwen surely would be aware of it, is that a lot of people being trained for the law are not going to practise law. being trained in the law, as with those who do economics or commerce or whatever, go into much broader areas of life. drivers, that you need a degree in law to drive a taxi, unless you are getting pulled over by the police every day and you want to be able to argue your case cogently. But I would argue-and I wonder how the member who spoke before me would contest this-that you people in the government have not been averse to attempting to control doctors' fees by interfering directly in the practice of medicine and effectively, de facto, almost nationalising them.

The honourable member has just attempted to argue-and it is a matter of self-preservation, I guess-that there are too many lawyers. The honourable member says in Melbourne that there is one on every comer. I assume he is saying that that is not a good thing. From the point of view of the provision of legal services, he would surely have to acknowledge that that may be a good thing if it puts a brake on the price of legal services. economics in any respect. The legal profession has argued amongst itself about whether or not it should be able to advertise. It seemed to me to some extent self-evident that allowing members of the profession to advertise would also tend to promote competition which we would be committed to on this side of the House. This would therefore force down the price of legal services. To take a medical analogy, if we wanted an orthopaedic surgeon to do a job, that would require a high degree of skill, and there are clearly not a lot of people with those skills because they take many years to acquire. I take it that the same thing would apply if we had a difficult legal case and we needed to be represented by a highly competent lawyer who is skilled in advocacy. The division in the profession makes a lot of sense. There are people who are barristers, who have that particular skill in advocacy. For that reason, I am not sure that the move that seems to be in vogue to disband that differentiation is necessarily going to be productive. I am not necessarily even arguing that barristers' fees are too high. If we want someone with that skill and knowledge, and not many people have the skill or knowledge, obviously the price is affected. In a sense, it is a fairly good market; it is almost a perfect market in terms of availability of knowledge. However, I agree that, on the supply side, it is the same as getting an orthopaedic surgeon. There is obviously a limited number of orthopaedic surgeons; there is a big demand for their services; and the price goes up. It is difficult to increase the supply side. It is difficult to increase the supply side of highly skilled barristers or advocates. I wanted to make that point. As I say, I am arguing as a layman. The average person in the street would surely take the same view, that we really do not have too many lawyers-and I would not necessarily argue this in the same way with my legal friends. The more lawyers there are, the more likely it is that the price of legal services will come down. If. as the honourable member tells me, the price of legal services has gone up at the same time as there are more lawyers, this would run contrary to any law of economics I had ever learned at university. There would be something going on that perhaps the Trade Practices Commission ought to look into because it should not be happening. Allowing lawyers to advertise would also put a brake on prices or charges-however one wants to put it. They are some of issues but, as I say, I am not an expert in these things. I will make a brief comment about legal aid. Once again, having glanced through the report, and I am not speaking as a lawyer but as a member of parliament, it seems to me that there are huge problems with access to legal aid. I do not know that the report solves the problem but I notice it has established one of the three crucial objectives in achieving access to justice: regardless of means, all Australians should have access to legal services. They clearly do not; they just do not.

Not one week goes by in my office-and I think probably almost every honourable member of parliament would concur; the honourable member for Brisbane( Mr Bevis) I am sure would concur-without someone coming to me, needing access to justice. People do not have the funds. Very often they need access to justice because their business has gone broke and they are absolutely destitute. They have not got a cent. The same thing would apply in a family law matter. Often an enormous amount of pressure is applied by the husband who, for one reason or another, has got the family assets; the wife is destitute and needs a lawyer to act for her, but she cannot get legal aid. I take it from reading this report there is a general acknowledgment that there are limits to the amount of money that is available. There are limits to the amount of money that is available to do anything. The problem of governments, I guess, is that it is limited. It is the basic economic problem, if we want to get back to economics, of limited means and unlimited demands or wants. Somehow the system is not serving its purpose. There is a fundamental breakdown here. I see it as a member of parliament. Not a week goes by without my having people in my office who have no access to justice. They have not got any money so they cannot go and hire a lawyer. They need a lawyer. I am no help to them in a legal sense; they need a lawyer. I send them down to the local legal aid office or I contact the local legal aid office. I really know the answer before I phone because those offices have so restricted the sorts of things that they are prepared to fund that I know before asking that they are not going to fund this particular matter.
